text:
Park Avenue, south from 56th Street, where the railroad emerges from the tunnel and the Grand Central Yards begin.
The Avenue will be built over the tracks to 52nd Street by 1910 and to the new station by 1913, and the railroad electrified.
On west side, note houses between 54th and 53rd Street, which will still be standing thirty years later.
On the east side, note old Steinway Piano Factory, dating back to the Civil War or earlier, which will be demolished in 1911.
Beyond it may be seen the tower of R&M Scheefer's brewery, about the same age, on the S. E. corner of 51st Street where the new St. Bartholomew's Church will be built in 1918.
Compre with the Edison Company's photograph of the same scene in 1927.

New York Edison Company Collection.

June 10, 1905.
44 E 51st Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of Park Ave. 1912.

Park Avenue, east side, from 51st to 52nd Street. Part of the old F&M Schaefer Brewery, about to be demolished in the block where the Ambassador Hotel is to be built. In the block below, which has been purchased By St. Bartholomew's church, the main part of the old brewery has already been demolished. 1917.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

121 East 5th Street, northside between Park and Lexington Avenues showing P.S. 18.

Board of Education, N.Y.C.

1920

Glossy Photo. Not Negative available in H & G. Neg. No. 168.

Park Avenue, north from 51st Street, about 9:30 A.M., showing buildings along east side. It is possible to see nearly a mile of the Avenue. Notice Hotel Ambassador, 51st to 52d Streets, built in 1919 and the Montane Apartments (1912) between 52nd and 53rd Streets. The tiny building on the N.E. corner of 53rd Street is a survival of the era before the railroad was electrified, about 1924 it will be demolished. No. 441, in the N.E. corner of 56th Street, also dates back to the 1880's. Note cross-town street-cars at 59th Street. 1921.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

51st Street west from east of Park Avenue.
April 8, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.

Park Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 54th Street.
July 11, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue, north from and including 51st Street, showing buildings along the west side, also the parks in the center, shaved to make room for more traffic.
The five-story building between 52nd and 53rd Street is the Racquet and Tennis Club, and behind it on the horizon rises the Tower of the Fuller Building at Madison Avenue and 57th Street.
The small buildings in the block above, 53rd to 54th Street, are much older than their surroundings, dating back to at least 1890.
On the east side, just north of St. Bartholomew's, is the Hotel Ambassador. Summer 1929.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

51st Street, north side, between Lexington and Park Avenues, with Public School No. 18 in the centre, and the Hotel Ambassador on the left.

May 3, 1930.

P.L. Sperr.

Hotel Ambassador (built 1918-19), Park Avenue, east side, from 51st to 52nd Streets. Compare this photograph with the same scene in 1917.

About 1932.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

A general view of the Grand Central Zone as viewed southward on Park Ave. from East 52nd Street, at which point appears the Hotel Ambassador (left foreground) with St. Bartholomew's P.E. Church just beyond (S.E. corner of 51st Street). Prominently shown (centre) is the new Waldorf Astoria Hotel flanked on one side by the R.C.A. Building and the Chrysler, Chanin, Grand Central Palace and Lincoln Buildings on the other. Distinctly shown between the R.C.A. Building and the Waldorf Astoria Hotel is Tudor City located near the East River, which is dimly apparent on the left.

October 31, 1932.

Wurts Brothers.

This photograph was used in NYPL Art Deco exhibit, Apr 30, 1975.

51st Street, south side, from Park to Madison Avenues.

May 15, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

St. Bartholomew's Church, Waldorf Astoria Hotel, General Electric Building.
Park Avenue and 51st Street, Manhattan

[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York] Code IA3
April 2, 1936
